content.description:
Dystrophin is a protein that is expressed in certain muscle cells. In combination with other cellular proteins, dystrophin strengthens protein fibers in muscle cells to allow muscles to contract without injury.

Nucleotide deletions in the gene that encodes dystrophin are associated with the genetic disorder Duchenne Muscular Dystrophy (<math alttext="D M D" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>DMD</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>). Individuals with <math alttext="D M D" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>DMD</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> do not produce functional dystrophin and, as a result, the protein fibers, and then entire muscle cells, become damaged.

The history of <math alttext="D M D" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>DMD</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> for three generations of a family is shown in Figure 1.

Figure 1. Pedigree showing instances of <math alttext="D M D" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>DMD</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> in a family

Individuals <math alttext="1 in generation 3" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>III</mtext><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">–</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="2 in generation 3" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>III</mtext><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">–</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> plan to have children and wish to first determine whether individual <math alttext="2 in generation 3" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>III</mtext><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">–</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> is a carrier of <math alttext="D M D" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>DMD</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. Individual <math alttext="2 in generation 3" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>III</mtext><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">–</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> undergoes genetic testing to determine whether individual <math alttext="2 in generation 3" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mtext>III-2</mtext></math> carries a particular allele for the mutated dystrophin that is associated with the disorder in this family. The results of gel electrophoresis analysis of the individual’s dystrophin alleles and the alleles of several family members are shown in Figure 2.

Figure 2. Gel electrophoresis showing the dystrophin alleles present in five members of the family
content.question:
Another form of muscular dystrophy, <math alttext="B M D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>BMD</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, has a less severe phenotype. Individuals with <math alttext="B M D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>BMD</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> produce less dystrophin protein or abnormal dystrophin protein with reduced function, whereas individuals with <math alttext="D M D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>DMD</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> produce no dystrophin protein. Both <math alttext="B M D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>BMD</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="D M D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>DMD</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> are commonly caused by the deletion of a portion of the dystrophin gene.

Which of the following best explains why there is a difference in phenotype between <math alttext="B M D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>BMD</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="D M D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>DMD</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>?

choices.label: <math alttext="B M D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>BMD</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> can be caused by the deletion of exons, while <math alttext="D M D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>DMD</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is caused by the deletion of introns.

<math alttext="B M D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>BMD</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> can be caused by a deletion that affects a single amino acid, while <math alttext="D M D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>DMD</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is caused by a deletion that alters all the amino acids that follow the mutation.

<math alttext="B M D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>BMD</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> can be caused by a deletion that removes the transcription start site, while <math alttext="D M D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>DMD</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is caused by a deletion that removes the transcription stop signal.

<math alttext="B M D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>BMD</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> can be caused by the inheritance of two alleles containing deletions, while <math alttext="D M D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>DMD</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is caused by the inheritance of one allele containing the deletion and one normal allele.

content.answer: <math alttext="B M D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>BMD</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> can be caused by a deletion that affects a single amino acid, while <math alttext="D M D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>DMD</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is caused by a deletion that alters all the amino acids that follow the mutation.

skill.text: 1.C: Explain biological concepts and processes in applied contexts.
